Award.AbstractNarration:
This research centers on the problem of designing and analyzing matrix recovery algorithms using the breakthrough "approximate message-passing" (AMP) framework that was recently proposed in the context of compressive sensing. The matrix recovery problems considered in this project include matrix completion, robust PCA, dictionary learning, compressive sensing under matrix uncertainty, and multinomial classification, where the goal is to recover a pair of matrices from noisy observations of their product, where the observations may be warped by element-wise nonlinearities, and where the matrices may include structure such as group sparsity, non-negativity, and per-row/vector norm constraints. Such problems arise frequently across many subdisciplines of engineering, science, and medicine, and with ever increasing data sizes. Thus, there is a great need for an algorithmic approach that is accurate, robust, and computationally efficient.

In particular, the research involves 1) the extension of AMP methods from linear inference (as in compressive sensing) to bilinear inference, 2) the integration of message passing strategies inspired by turbo-decoding in communications that facilitate the exploitation of sophisticated structural priors, 3) the development of empirical-Bayesian methods that automatically tune the parameters modeling the signal prior as well as the observation prior, 4) the explicit treatment of uncertainty in the assumed model, and 5) the exploitation of the AMP state-evolution framework for rigorous performance analysis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goals of this project were 1) the design of approximate-message-passing (AMP) algorithms for problems beyond compressive sensing, such as matrix completion, robust PCA, dictionary learning, non-negative matrix factorization, and classification; and 2) the application of those algorithms to practical engineering problems such as multi-voxel pattern analysis, hyperspectral image unmixing, and demodulation of communications signals.


The outcomes of the project were as follows.


We proposed a generalized approximate-message-passing (G-AMP) based algorithm for the recovery of matrices A and X from a measurement of their product Z=AX observed through a probabilistic channel, called "BiG-AMP".  Extensive numerical experiments demonstrate state-of-the-art recovery performance for matrix completion, robust PCA, dictionary learning, and non-negative matrix factorization (NNMF).


We designed a novel approach to hyperspectral image (HSI) unmixing, which merges BiG-AMP with Markov models to exploit both spatial coherence among the abundances and spectral coherence within the end-members.  Numerical simulations on synthetic and experimental datasets demonstrate favorable unmixing performance relative to existing methods.


We designed new algorithms for binary linear classification and feature selection using the G-AMP framework.  Our algorithms support both MAP and MMSE forms of logistic, probit, and hinge-loss activation functions, and induce sparsity in the weight vector.  Numerical experiments confirmed excellent performance on fMRI-based multi-voxel pattern analysis and text mining, and agreement with state-evolution predictions.


We designed an efficient communications receiver for impulsive-noise corrupted (e.g., power-line) applications.  Merging techniques from G-AMP, robust PCA, and belief-propagation decoding, we designed an efficient approach to joint impulse-estimation, channel-estimation, equalization, and decoding of OFDM signals.  Numerical experiments show performance far exceeding existing methods and close to information-theoretic bounds.


We designed a new algorithm for compressive phase retrieval, i.e., recovery of a signal from noisy, phase-less, sub-Nyquist linear measurements, based on the G-AMP framework.  We demonstrated that our method yields state-of-the-art mean-squared recovery error, phase transitions, and runtime, making possible the accurate recovery of mega-pixel images in under a minute on a standard PC.


We designed a novel G-AMP-based algorithm for parametric bilinear inference problems, called "P-BiG-AMP".  This generalization of BiG-AMP applies to generic bilinear inference problems, not just models like Z=AX.  Numerical results demonstrated that it yields state-of-the-art performance in applications such as matrix compressive sensing, blind deconvolution, and self-calibration. 


We designed new approximate-message-passing based algorithms for multinomial logistic regression (MLR), which extend the aforementioned classification work from binary to M-ary labels.  Using both synthetic and real-world datasets (on micro-array gene expression, text mining, handwritten-digit), we demonstrate improved error-rate and runtime performance relative to existing state-of-the-art approaches to sparse MLR.
